text: Hey, what's up creators and welcome back
to the first hour of Unreal Engine
course. In this video, we're going to
kick off the functionality for our coin
counting system. So, in the last video,
we set up our coins so that way we have
them in the level. They're gold, they're
spinning, and they look fantastic. But
now, what I want to do is start setting
up the foundation for our blueprints so
that way our character can collect
these. So, what we're going to be doing
in this video is first things first,
just making sure that we have got the
right character blueprint active in our
level. And then secondly, we're going to
be showing you how we can set up all of
the variables for our coin counting
system so we know how many coins the
character has currently got and what is
the maximum amount that they can collect
as well. And then from there, we're just
going to be developing this further.
Let's jump straight into Unreal Engine
and set up our character blueprint. So,
back inside of Unreal Engine, the first
thing that we need to do is make sure
that we're using the right player
blueprint and then start building some
variables, some data for how many coins
has been collected inside of there. The
way we're going to do this is by going
into our content drawer. Then what I
want you to do is find your variant
platforming,
go to blueprints, and the character
blueprint that we're actually going to
be using for this is BP platforming
character. The reason for this is this
character actually comes with some
really cool abilities for things like
dashing or sprinting and double jumping
as part of this template. We are no
longer just going to use that simple
third person character that we saw
earlier on. So to make sure that we're
actually using this in a given level,
what you need to do is go to window and
then world settings, make sure this is
turned on and then underneath your game
mode override, I just want you to make
sure you go ahead and choose
bp_platforming
game mode.
With this done, if I go ahead and press
play now, it looks like that regular
third person character, except if I
jump, you can see we've got that trail
on our feet. And I can double jump. I
can jump off of things. I can press
shift to dash. And this all looks really
cool. And this is going to be some
really nice behavior which is going to
form the foundation of our platformer
game. So, now that we've got our
character blueprint working in our
level, let's take a look at how we can
actually start having logic in there for
our coin collectibles. And what we're
going to do is open up that blueprint
for the character. Just go to variant
platforming blueprints and then open it
up. The way we're going to do this is by
using something called variables.
Variables are essentially just data. And
this data can come in many many
different forms. It could be text, it
could be numbers, could be anything. In
this case, we want some data for how
many coins have been collected and also
what is the total number of coins that
need to be collected. Let's set this
data up so we can start writing some
blueprint code. To create these
variables inside of our platforming
blueprint character,
we are going to go and find our
variables down at the bottom here. And
what we're going to do is we're going to
press plus variable.
And we're just going to call this
variable collected coins.
Now, what it's also asking for in
addition to the name is a variable type.
There's a couple different types of
variables in here. And again, as you
move through your Unreal Engine learning
journey, you're going to get to know
what all of these are, but I'm going to
give you a very brief overview of some
of these. You've got boolean, which is
just whether or not a piece of data is
true or false.
You've got integer, which is going to be
a whole number, so 1 2 3 4. Floats,
which is going to be decimal places. And
then we've also got text and strings,
which is going to allow you to add text
in there. There's a lot more of these,
but I'm not going to explain them for
now. In terms of the number of coins
that they have collected, it's not going
to be something that needs a decimal
place because they've either collected a
whole coin or they haven't. We're going
to choose the variable type integer.
Go ahead and compile this. And that is
now your first variable created. In the
details panel on the right hand side,
you have got a whole bunch of
information about this variable. The
main one we want to be concerned about
for now is the default value. The
default value is currently set to zero.
That's exactly what we want because the
player hasn't collected any coins. We
don't want this variable to say
otherwise. Now, we're going to create
another variable
and we're just going to call this max
coins.
This max coins variable is essentially
going to tell us or our blueprint logic
what is the maximum amount of coins that
the player needs to collect to complete
the game.
Again, this is going to be a whole
number. So, I'm going to use the integer
type. I'm going to compile this and then
I can choose a number. For now, I'm
going to go with a number five. We can
change this later on. Once you have done
this, go ahead and compile this and
minimize it. So, that's everything that
I wanted to show you for this video. In
the next video, we're going to be
showing you how we can actually start
communicating with our character and our
coin blueprint to start bringing all of
this together. But right now, we've got
the foundation and we're ready. Move on
to the next video to continue your
Unreal Engine learning journey. And as
always, stay awesome, keep creating.
